headline: On trip to border, McCarthy deflects questions about Trump and Jan. 6
sentences:

The latest: Greene brought up martial law in texts to Meadows
Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) told White House chief of staff Mark Meadows that some members of Congress were suggesting that Donald Trump impose martial law to remain in office after losing the 2020 election.

Congress is also waiting for Biden to ask for a supplemental package of military and humanitarian assistance for Ukraine, which the House hopes to pass this week.The Senate will be heavily focused on voting through several Federal Reserve and Federal Trade Commission nominees this week, as well as coordinating with the House on jump-starting conversations about domestic issues of importance, including the defunct social spending plan known as Build Back Better and a coronavirus relief package.It is also expected that both chambers will begin ironing out differences over the Bipartisan Innovation Act, a massive global competitiveness bill, as early as Tuesday.

In texts provided to CNN by the House select committee investigating the deadly Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection, Greene raised the topic of martial law in a message to Meadows sent on Jan. 17, 2021, more than a week after the insurrection and three days before Bidens inauguration, Felicia Sonmez reports:
In our private chat with only Members, several are saying the only way to save our Republic is for Trump to call for Marshall law,? Greene texted Meadows, misspelling the word martial.? I dont know on those things.

On Wednesday, the president and first lady are hosting the national and state teachers of the year at the White House.Biden is also eulogizing former secretary of state Madeleine Albright at her funeral Wednesday morning at the Washington National Cathedral.And on Saturday, he is planning to attend the White House Correspondents Association dinner, the first time a sitting president has attended the gathering since 2016 given that former president Donald Trump skipped it.

Biden is also slated to meet with the Congressional Hispanic Caucus on Monday, when a key topic of discussion is likely to be Title 42 border restrictions, something the group wants repealed but some moderate Democrats want to continue.Biden this week also has several other items on the agenda, including welcoming the Tampa Bay Lightning to the White House on Monday to celebrate its 2020 and 2021 Stanley Cup championships.

Today, House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy led a group of fellow Republicans on a tour of the U.S.-Mexico border to highlight President Bidens border crisis.? Facing reporters, McCarthy (R-Calif.) deflected questions stemming from his dishonesty after the release of audio that captured him saying that President Donald Trump was to blame for the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and should resign.

Samantha Pell: Lightning coming to the White House lawn  The Tampa Bay Lightning hockey team is visiting the White House on Monday to celebrate its 2020 and 2021 Stanley Cup championships.The Lightning did not visit the White House the past two years because of coronavirus concerns  nor did the team visit after its 2004 Stanley Cup victory because of a National Hockey League lockout.

The mixed response to lifting the mask mandate  some cities and transit authorities have said they will still require masks, while others completely got rid of them, and plenty of airlines quickly ditched them  shows how the patchwork policies that have abounded during this crisis can lead to a loss in confidence in the public health agency.

The latest: McCarthy keeps dodging questions on Trump and Jan. 6
House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) continued dodging questions about a New York Times revelations that he told other Republicans he would urge Donald Trump to resign in the wake of the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection, Felicia Sonmez reports.

President Biden is expected to be in Washington all this week, with meetings scheduled with congressional leaders amid questions about key elements of his legislative priorities.Priorities for the White House include a covid aid funding bill, Ukraine aid legislation and trying to salvage parts of its Build Back Better agenda.
